title: Jeremiah Chapter 13 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 13 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 13 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 13.

questions.question: What did the LORD command Jeremiah to get in Jeremiah 13:1?
options: A linen girdle
A clay jar
A scroll
A staff
questions.correctAnswer: A linen girdle
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:1 states that the LORD told Jeremiah to get a linen girdle.

questions.question: Where was Jeremiah instructed to hide the girdle according to Jeremiah 13:4?
options: In a hole of the rock by Euphrates
Underneath the temple altar
In the king's palace
In the wilderness of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: In a hole of the rock by Euphrates
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:4 commands Jeremiah to hide the girdle in a hole of the rock by the Euphrates river.

questions.question: What happened to the girdle when Jeremiah retrieved it from the Euphrates?
options: It was marred and good for nothing
It was as new as before
It was missing
It was turned into gold
questions.correctAnswer: It was marred and good for nothing
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:7 states that the girdle was marred and profitable for nothing when taken from the place it was hidden.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 13:9, what will God mar?
options: The pride of Judah and Jerusalem
The walls of Jerusalem
The hearts of the prophets
The land of Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: The pride of Judah and Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:9 says God will mar the pride of Judah and the great pride of Jerusalem.

questions.question: What do the people of Judah do that is compared to the ruined girdle in Jeremiah 13:10?
options: Refuse to hear God's words and worship other gods
Build altars to the LORD
Fast and pray earnestly
Gather in Jerusalem for worship
questions.correctAnswer: Refuse to hear God's words and worship other gods
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:10 describes the people as refusing to hear God's words and walking after other gods, like the girdle that is good for nothing.

questions.question: How does the LORD describe His relationship to Israel and Judah in Jeremiah 13:11?
options: As a girdle cleaving to the loins of a man
Like a shepherd to his sheep
Like a potter to clay
Like a vine to its branches
questions.correctAnswer: As a girdle cleaving to the loins of a man
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:11 states God caused Israel and Judah to cleave to Him as a girdle cleaveth to the loins of a man.

questions.question: What will happen to every bottle according to Jeremiah 13:12?
options: Every bottle shall be filled with wine
Every bottle shall be broken
Every bottle shall be sealed
Every bottle shall be empty
questions.correctAnswer: Every bottle shall be filled with wine
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:12 says every bottle shall be filled with wine, as a prophetic sign.

questions.question: Who will be filled with drunkenness according to Jeremiah 13:13?
options: Kings, priests, prophets, and all inhabitants of Jerusalem
Only the prophets
The foreigners in the land
The poor and widows
questions.correctAnswer: Kings, priests, prophets, and all inhabitants of Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:13 states that all inhabitants including kings, priests, and prophets will be filled with drunkenness.

questions.question: What does God say He will do to the fathers and sons in Jeremiah 13:14?
options: Dash them one against another
Bless them with peace
Gather them in safety
Make them rulers over other nations
questions.correctAnswer: Dash them one against another
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:14 says God will dash fathers and sons one against another without pity or mercy.

questions.question: What warning is given in Jeremiah 13:16 about giving glory to God?
options: Give glory before darkness and stumbling come
Give glory only after victory
Give glory when you feel thankful
Give glory only in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Give glory before darkness and stumbling come
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:16 advises giving glory to God before darkness causes feet to stumble.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 13:23 states that the Ethiopian can change his skin and the leopard his spots.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:23 says the Ethiopian cannot change his skin nor the leopard his spots, used as a metaphor that those accustomed to evil cannot do good.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 13:17 expresses that the LORD'S soul will rejoice if the people do not hear His words.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:17 states that the LORD'S soul shall weep in secret places if the people do not hear, showing sorrow rather than joy.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 13:19 says the cities of the south will be shut up and none shall open them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:19 confirms that the cities of the south shall be shut up and none shall open them.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Jeremiah 13:22: 'For the greatness of thine iniquity are thy ______ discovered, and thy heels made bare.'
options: skirts
hands
feet
eyes
questions.correctAnswer: skirts
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:22 says 'For the greatness of thine iniquity are thy skirts discovered, and thy heels made bare.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Jeremiah 13:26: 'Therefore will I discover thy ______ upon thy face, that thy shame may appear.'
options: skirts
sins
sins
shame
questions.correctAnswer: skirts
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:26 uses 'skirts' to symbolize exposure and shame.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 13 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 13 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with pride and disobedience. Based on Jeremiah 13, what biblical truth would you share about humility?
options: Pride leads to destruction and God's judgment
Pride is a sign of strong faith
Humility is not necessary for God's favor
God overlooks pride in His people
questions.correctAnswer: Pride leads to destruction and God's judgment
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:9-10, 13:14, and 13:15 warn that pride causes God's judgment and destruction, urging humility instead.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 13 illustrate the importance of obedience to God's commands?
options: Obedience leads to God's favor and protection
Obedience is optional for believers
Disobedience causes one to become 'good for nothing' like the ruined girdle
God rewards disobedience to test faith
questions.correctAnswer: Disobedience causes one to become 'good for nothing' like the ruined girdle
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:7-10 shows the girdle becoming marred and useless as a symbol of Judah's disobedience and its consequences.

questions.question: What spiritual discipline does Jeremiah 13 suggest for those who face trials and persecution?
options: Humbling oneself and giving glory to God before darkness comes
Ignoring trials and focusing on worldly success
Avoiding prayer and fellowship during hardships
Relying solely on personal strength
questions.correctAnswer: Humbling oneself and giving glory to God before darkness comes
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:15-16 emphasizes humbling oneself and giving glory to God to avoid spiritual darkness and stumbling.

questions.question: A believer asks how to remain faithful when surrounded by others who reject God's word. What does Jeremiah 13 teach about God’s relationship with His people?
options: God desires His people to cleave to Him as a girdle cleaves to the waist
God only cares for those who never fail
God abandons those who disobey immediately
God’s love is conditional on perfect behavior
questions.correctAnswer: God desires His people to cleave to Him as a girdle cleaves to the waist
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:11 describes God's desire for Israel and Judah to be closely joined to Him, like a girdle to the loins.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 13 warn about the consequences of unrepentant sin in families and communities?
options: God will dash fathers and sons together without mercy
Sin has no effect on family relations
God rewards sin with peace
Family unity prevents God's judgment
questions.correctAnswer: God will dash fathers and sons together without mercy
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:14 warns that unrepentant sin leads to harsh judgment, even breaking family bonds.

questions.question: A believer struggling with temptation asks for guidance on change. What does Jeremiah 13 say about the possibility of changing sinful habits?
options: Those accustomed to evil need God's power to change, like the Ethiopian cannot change his skin
Change is impossible for anyone
People can change through their own efforts alone
Sinful habits are easily changed without help
questions.correctAnswer: Those accustomed to evil need God's power to change, like the Ethiopian cannot change his skin
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:23 uses the metaphor of an Ethiopian changing skin to illustrate the difficulty of changing sinful behavior without divine help.

questions.question: What practical lesson about integrity and faithfulness in daily life can be drawn from the symbol of the linen girdle in Jeremiah 13?
options: Faithfulness to God is essential or one becomes like the ruined girdle, useless
Integrity is unrelated to spiritual obedience
One can ignore God's words and still be faithful
Daily life has no bearing on spiritual condition
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness to God is essential or one becomes like the ruined girdle, useless
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:6-10 shows the girdle becoming marred when hidden, symbolizing how unfaithfulness renders one useless to God.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 13 teaches that God will show mercy despite persistent pride and rebellion without consequence.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:14 specifically states God will not have mercy nor spare those who persist in pride and rebellion.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 13 encourages believers to listen and obey God's words to avoid spiritual darkness and stumbling.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:15-16 calls for hearing and humility to prevent stumbling in darkness, emphasizing obedience.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 13 encourage believers to respond when facing God's discipline and captivity?
options: Humble themselves and recognize their iniquity
Blame others without self-examination
Ignore the warnings and continue as before
Seek revenge against oppressors
questions.correctAnswer: Humble themselves and recognize their iniquity
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:18-22 urges humility and acknowledgment of sin as a response to God’s discipline and captivity.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 13 teach about the importance of giving glory to God in times of uncertainty?
options: Giving glory to God prevents stumbling into darkness
Glory is only due when life is easy
Uncertainty means God is absent
Glory to God is irrelevant in hard times
questions.correctAnswer: Giving glory to God prevents stumbling into darkness
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:16 highlights the need to glorify God before darkness comes and causes stumbling.

questions.question: A believer wonders about the consequences of forgetting God and trusting in falsehood. What does Jeremiah 13 say will be their portion?
options: They will be scattered like stubble by the wind
They will prosper without consequence
They will be rewarded for their trust
God will immediately restore them
questions.correctAnswer: They will be scattered like stubble by the wind
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:24-25 explains that forgetting God and trusting falsehood results in being scattered like stubble.

questions.question: What warning does Jeremiah 13 give about leadership and its impact on a nation or family?
options: Bad leaders lead to punishment and sorrow upon those who appointed them
Leaders have no influence on their people
Good or bad leaders make no difference
Leaders are always protected by God regardless of actions
questions.correctAnswer: Bad leaders lead to punishment and sorrow upon those who appointed them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:21 questions what one will say when punished for appointing captains who lead to sorrow.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 13 compares the people of Israel and Judah to a _____ that cleaves to the loins, symbolizing their intended closeness to God.
options: linen girdle
stone
vine
bottle
questions.correctAnswer: linen girdle
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:11 uses the linen girdle cleaving to the loins as a metaphor for Israel and Judah's intended close relationship with God.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 13 teach about repentance and cleansing for those involved in spiritual adultery?
options: Woe to Jerusalem for their lewdness; they must be made clean
Spiritual adultery is tolerated by God
There is no hope for those who sin
God ignores unfaithfulness
questions.correctAnswer: Woe to Jerusalem for their lewdness; they must be made clean
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:27 pronounces woe due to adulteries and calls for cleansing of Jerusalem’s spiritual lewdness.

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 13 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 13.

questions.question: What object did the LORD command Jeremiah to obtain and wear on his loins as a symbolic act?
options: A linen girdle
A golden crown
A wooden staff
A leather belt
questions.correctAnswer: A linen girdle
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:1 states that the LORD instructed Jeremiah to get a linen girdle and put it on his loins as a prophetic sign.

questions.question: What was Jeremiah commanded to do with the girdle after putting it on his loins?
options: Hide it in a hole of the rock by the Euphrates
Throw it into the river
Burn it on an altar
Give it to the priests
questions.correctAnswer: Hide it in a hole of the rock by the Euphrates
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:4 directs Jeremiah to take the girdle and hide it in a hole of the rock by the Euphrates, symbolizing the fate of Judah.

questions.question: What did Jeremiah find when he retrieved the girdle from the Euphrates?
options: It was marred and good for nothing
It was as strong as before
It had turned to gold
It was missing
questions.correctAnswer: It was marred and good for nothing
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:7 describes that the girdle was found marred and useless, symbolizing the ruined state of Judah due to pride and disobedience.

questions.question: What does the marred girdle symbolize according to the LORD's explanation?
options: The pride of Judah and Jerusalem marred by their disobedience
The strength of Israel's enemies
The protection of God's people
The restoration of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: The pride of Judah and Jerusalem marred by their disobedience
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:9 explains that the marred girdle represents God's judgment on the pride of Judah and Jerusalem due to their refusal to hear His word.

questions.question: How does the LORD describe the relationship between Himself and the house of Israel and Judah?
options: Like a girdle cleaving to a man's loins
Like a shepherd to his sheep
Like a king to his subjects
Like a father to his children
questions.correctAnswer: Like a girdle cleaving to a man's loins
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:11 uses the metaphor of a girdle cleaving to the loins to illustrate the close relationship God intended with Israel and Judah.

questions.question: What prophecy does Jeremiah give about the inhabitants of the land, including kings, priests, and prophets?
options: They will be filled with drunkenness
They will conquer their enemies
They will repent and be restored
They will build a temple
questions.correctAnswer: They will be filled with drunkenness
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:13 prophesies that all inhabitants, including leaders, will be filled with drunkenness as a symbol of judgment and chaos.

questions.question: What is the consequence described for the fathers and sons according to the LORD's declaration?
options: They will be dashed one against another
They will live in peace
They will prosper in the land
They will be saved from captivity
questions.correctAnswer: They will be dashed one against another
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:14 states the LORD will cause strife even between fathers and sons as part of the impending judgment.

questions.question: What warning does the LORD give about pride in Jeremiah 13?
options: Be not proud, for the LORD hath spoken
Pride will lead to victory
Pride is the path to wisdom
Pride will bring wealth
questions.correctAnswer: Be not proud, for the LORD hath spoken
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:15 warns the people against pride, emphasizing God's authority and the consequences of ignoring His word.

questions.question: What does the LORD urge the people to do before darkness and stumbling come upon them?
options: Give glory to the LORD your God
Build strong fortifications
Offer sacrifices to other gods
Flee to the mountains
questions.correctAnswer: Give glory to the LORD your God
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:16 calls for giving glory to God before calamity overtakes them, emphasizing repentance and recognition of God's sovereignty.

questions.question: What emotion does Jeremiah say his soul will experience if the people do not hear the LORD's word?
options: Weeping in secret places
Joy and gladness
Anger and rage
Indifference
questions.correctAnswer: Weeping in secret places
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:17 expresses Jeremiah's deep sorrow and compassion for the people's pride and impending captivity.

questions.question: To whom does Jeremiah specifically address the command to humble themselves and sit down?
options: The king and the queen
The priests and prophets
The elders and judges
The merchants and farmers
questions.correctAnswer: The king and the queen
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:18 directs this warning towards the royal leadership, highlighting their accountability in Jerusalem's judgment.

questions.question: What fate is described for the cities of the south in this chapter?
options: They shall be shut up and none shall open them
They shall be rebuilt and prosper
They shall be given as gifts to foreign kings
They shall be flooded
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be shut up and none shall open them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:19 forewarns that the cities of the south will be closed, signaling captivity and desolation.

questions.question: What rhetorical question does Jeremiah use to illustrate the impossibility of change for those accustomed to evil?
options: Can the Ethiopian change his skin, or the leopard his spots?
Can a lion change its roar?
Can the river reverse its course?
Can the mountain move from its place?
questions.correctAnswer: Can the Ethiopian change his skin, or the leopard his spots?
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:23 uses this well-known proverb to illustrate the stubbornness of sin and the difficulty of repentance for habitual evildoers.

questions.question: What is declared as the ultimate reason for Judah's judgment and scattering?
options: Because they have forgotten the LORD and trusted in falsehood
Because they failed to build the temple
Because they worshipped the true God only
Because they were too powerful
questions.correctAnswer: Because they have forgotten the LORD and trusted in falsehood
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:25 reveals that the root cause of Judah's calamity is their abandonment of God and reliance on lies.

questions.question: True or False: The LORD promises to have mercy and spare the people despite their pride.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:14 explicitly states the LORD will not pity, spare, or have mercy but will destroy them because of their sin and pride.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 13 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 13 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the symbolic object God instructed Jeremiah to obtain and wear on his loins without washing?
options: A linen girdle
A leather belt
A golden chain
A woolen cloak
questions.correctAnswer: A linen girdle
questions.explanation: God commanded Jeremiah to take a linen girdle and put it on his loins without putting it in water, symbolizing Israel's close relationship with God that was to remain pure but became corrupted (Jeremiah 13:1-2). This reflects God's covenantal relationship with His people (Ezekiel 16:8; Hosea 2:19; John 15:1-5; Revelation 3:4).

questions.question: Where did God instruct Jeremiah to hide the linen girdle to illustrate the spiritual state of Judah?
options: In a hole of the rock by Euphrates
Under the altar in the temple
In the city gate
In a desert cave
questions.correctAnswer: In a hole of the rock by Euphrates
questions.explanation: Jeremiah was told to hide the girdle in a hole of the rock by the Euphrates, representing how Israel's pride and covenant relationship would be ruined and hidden away, similar to how the girdle became marred (Jeremiah 13:4-5). This act reflects God's judgment on His people's pride and rebellion (Isaiah 51:1-2; Hosea 7:8; Ezekiel 16:43; 2 Kings 17:18).

questions.question: What happened to the linen girdle after Jeremiah retrieved it from the Euphrates?
options: It was marred, profitable for nothing
It was as good as new
It was missing
It was doubled in length
questions.correctAnswer: It was marred, profitable for nothing
questions.explanation: The girdle was marred and became useless, symbolizing how Judah's pride and disobedience made them spiritually worthless and unable to fulfill their purpose (Jeremiah 13:7). This aligns with God's judgment on Israel's corruption (Psalm 89:39; Isaiah 1:6; Ezekiel 22:4; Romans 3:23).

questions.question: What does the marred girdle symbolize about the pride of Judah and Jerusalem?
options: God will mar their pride and make them useless
They will be exalted above other nations
They will be preserved forever
They will prosper without repentance
questions.correctAnswer: God will mar their pride and make them useless
questions.explanation: The marred girdle symbolizes God's judgment on the pride of Judah and Jerusalem, making them worthless because of their refusal to hear His word and idolatry (Jeremiah 13:9-10). This theme of judgment due to pride is consistent with Isaiah 2:11; Proverbs 16:18; Obadiah 1:3; James 4:6.

questions.question: How does God describe His relationship with the house of Israel and Judah in comparison to the girdle?
options: The house of Israel and Judah cleave to God as a girdle cleaves to the loins
They are as distant from God as the girdle is from the waist
They are like a broken girdle
They are like a crown on God's head
questions.correctAnswer: The house of Israel and Judah cleave to God as a girdle cleaves to the loins
questions.explanation: God says the whole house of Israel and Judah cleave unto Him as a girdle cleaves to the loins, showing an intended intimate and inseparable relationship, which they rejected (Jeremiah 13:11). This reflects covenant intimacy seen in Deuteronomy 10:20; Hosea 11:4; John 15:4-5; Ephesians 5:27.

questions.question: What analogy does God use to warn about the certainty of coming judgment involving wine?
options: Every bottle shall be filled with wine
The cup of wrath will be poured out
The wine will turn to blood
The vineyard will be destroyed
questions.correctAnswer: Every bottle shall be filled with wine
questions.explanation: God says every bottle shall be filled with wine as a metaphor of inevitable judgment and intoxication with divine wrath affecting all ranks, including kings, priests, and prophets (Jeremiah 13:12-13). This imagery is consistent with Isaiah 51:17; Habakkuk 2:16; Revelation 14:10; Luke 21:34.

questions.question: What is God's declared attitude toward the people during the coming judgment?
options: He will not have pity, spare, nor have mercy, but destroy them
He will forgive them without conditions
He will save them all immediately
He will delay judgment indefinitely
questions.correctAnswer: He will not have pity, spare, nor have mercy, but destroy them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:14 states God will not show pity or mercy but will bring destruction because of persistent rebellion, reflecting the holiness of God and the seriousness of sin (Psalm 5:5; Nahum 1:3; Hebrews 10:31; Romans 1:18).

questions.question: What exhortation does God give to the people before the coming darkness and judgment?
options: Give glory to the LORD your God
Build more altars
Increase sacrifices without repentance
Rely on your own strength
questions.correctAnswer: Give glory to the LORD your God
questions.explanation: God commands giving glory to Him before darkness and stumbling come, emphasizing repentance and worship as means to avoid judgment (Jeremiah 13:16). This call to glorify God before judgment aligns with Psalm 29:2; Isaiah 60:1-3; 1 Corinthians 10:31; Revelation 4:11.

questions.question: What is the consequence if the people refuse to hear God's warning, as expressed through Jeremiah?
options: God's soul shall weep secretly for their pride
They will be immediately forgiven
They will prosper without consequence
They will be hidden from all calamity
questions.correctAnswer: God's soul shall weep secretly for their pride
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:17 reveals God's deep sorrow and secret weeping over the people's pride and impending captivity, highlighting divine grief over rejection, consistent with Ezekiel 9:4; Hosea 11:8; John 11:35; Romans 9:2.

questions.question: What warning is given specifically to the king and queen regarding their principalities?
options: They should humble themselves because their crowns will be taken down
They will reign eternally without fear
They will conquer all their enemies
They should build fortresses for protection
questions.correctAnswer: They should humble themselves because their crowns will be taken down
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:18 commands the king and queen to humble themselves because their glory and rule will be removed, emphasizing God's sovereignty over earthly powers (Psalm 75:6-7; Daniel 4:17; James 4:10; 1 Peter 5:6).

questions.question: What is the fate of the cities of the south as described in this chapter?
options: They shall be shut up and none shall open them
They will be rebuilt and flourish
They will be places of refuge
They will become centers of worship
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be shut up and none shall open them
questions.explanation: Verse 19 states the cities of the south will be shut and inaccessible, symbolizing total siege and captivity, consistent with prophetic themes of judgment and exile (2 Chronicles 36:17-21; Isaiah 6:11; Ezekiel 7:15; Lamentations 2:9).

questions.question: Who is coming from the north that Jeremiah is instructed to observe, and what does this signify?
options: Captors bringing exile, symbolized as the loss of the flock
Messengers bringing peace treaties
Merchants bringing goods
Prophets bringing good news
questions.correctAnswer: Captors bringing exile, symbolized as the loss of the flock
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:20 calls attention to those coming from the north taking away the 'flock,' signifying the Babylonian exile and God's judgment on Israel as His entrusted people (Psalm 124:6; Isaiah 10:5; Ezekiel 34:5-6; Matthew 10:6).

questions.question: What rhetorical question does God use to emphasize the impossibility of the people changing their evil ways?
options: Can the Ethiopian change his skin, or the leopard his spots?
Can a rock move by its own will?
Can a shepherd leave his sheep?
Can the sun refuse to shine?
questions.correctAnswer: Can the Ethiopian change his skin, or the leopard his spots?
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:23 uses this rhetorical question to highlight how habitual evil behavior is deeply ingrained and difficult to change without God's intervention, paralleling themes in Jeremiah 17:9; Romans 8:7; Ephesians 2:3; 2 Corinthians 5:17.

questions.question: What is the reason God gives for scattering the people as stubble before the wilderness wind?
options: Because they have forgotten God and trusted in falsehood
Because they worshiped the true God
Because they obeyed the law perfectly
Because they were humble and repentant
questions.correctAnswer: Because they have forgotten God and trusted in falsehood
questions.explanation: The scattering is due to their forgetting God and trusting lies (Jeremiah 13:24-25), illustrating the consequence of apostasy and idolatry (Deuteronomy 8:19; Psalm 81:11-12; Hosea 4:6; Colossians 2:8).

questions.question: What does God say He will do to expose the shame of Jerusalem and Judah?
options: He will discover their skirts upon their face
He will cover their sins forever
He will crown them with glory
He will hide them in secret places
questions.correctAnswer: He will discover their skirts upon their face
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 13:26 states God will reveal their shame openly as a form of judgment for their sins, symbolizing public exposure and disgrace before the nations (Isaiah 47:3; Ezekiel 16:37; Nahum 3:5; Revelation 6:15-17).
